title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States. The registry will be used to track epidemiology, collect health information on diagnosed patients, and describe the incidence and prevalence of the disease. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including the number of patients receiving treatment disaggregated by hospital. The registry aims to describe the incidence and prevalence of mesothelioma, facilitate research, examine associated factors, outline demographic factors, and make non-identifiable information available to the public for research and prevention efforts. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including demographics, risk factors, diagnosis markers, and prevalence information. The Secretary will consult with experts to develop a patient registry for mesothelioma, focusing on genetic and environmental risk factors, diagnosis markers, disease prevention, management, and outcomes measures. The Secretary will consult with non-Federal mesothelioma experts, including epidemiologists, representatives of national associations, health information technology experts, clinicians, and research scientists for the development of a patient registry. Coordination with other Federal agencies, such as the National Institutes of Health, will be ensured for sharing information and analysis from the registry. The Secretary will make information from the patient registry available to Federal departments, agencies, and the public. Privacy protections will be as stringent as HIPAA laws. Reports to Congress will be submitted within 18 months of enactment. The Secretary will submit reports to Congress outlining findings in the mesothelioma patient registry, future expansion plans, and partnerships with research and patient advocacy communities. The first report is due within 18 months of the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress after 4 years of enacting the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015. The report will cover the development and maintenance of the mesothelioma patient registry, the type of information collected, its use and availability, and the coordination of databases on mesothelioma.
